Description.val:
The FY 2019 funding request was reduced by $.072 million to reflect the Department of Navy's effort to support the Office of Management and Budget directed reforms for Efficiency and Effectiveness that include a lean, accountable, more efficient government.

Littoral Combat Ship (LCS) focused mission packages provide the operational commander with capabilities to perform littoral mine countermeasures (MCM) operations, a detect-to-engage capability to counter small boat threats (Surface Warfare (SUW)), and a detect-to-engage capability to counter enemy submarines (Anti-Submarine Warfare (ASW)). A mission package (MP) is a combination of warfare mission modules (MM) with specialized crew, support equipment, and vehicles, including embarked manned helicopters and unmanned aircraft and maritime systems. Mission Modules are packaged in a modular fashion so that they can be quickly swapped in and out pier side on any LCS platform. 

This BLI funds the procurement of MCM and SUW MP support containers and equipment that is common across the mission packages (Mission Package Computing Environment (MPCE), Technology Refresh of the Multi-Vehicle Communications System (MVCS), and Training Equipment).   

The Common Mission Modules Equipment (Line Item Number 1600) by itself or support containers by themselves do not comprise a MP and are only deployable as part of a Mission Module (MM). A MM is deployable and capable of meeting its focused mission requirements on an LCS only when it includes the full complement of Common Mission Modules Equipment combined with all the required mission systems.  

Other Related Budgets: BLIs: OPN 1601, OPN 1602, OPN 1603, OPN 4248, OPN 2622, OPN 2624, WPN 4221, WPN 4225, RDT&E 0603596N

[P40A / LM008 - MPCE]: Commercial Off The Shelf (COTS)- Based Common Computing environment will support legacy Mission Package (MP) Command & Control (C2) applications and transition to Modular Open Systems Approach (MOSA) & Navy Open Architecture Computing Environment (OACE). It also provides a common computing environment to support the execution of Mission Package Application Software (MPAS), the shipboard tactical software associated with each mission package that enables execution of its focused mission.  Includes installation and checkout on-board the seaframe.  In order to support the MPCE Sonar Signal Processing of the Escort Mission Module (EMM), the MPCE needs to be augmented to provide additional processing capabilities.  FY 2019 includes procurement of MPCE Sonar Signal Process equipment racks. These equipment racks will be co-located with the MPCE processing racks.  In addition, a Mission Package Portable Control Station (MPPCS) to support pre-deployment checkouts, to support shore-based and vessels of opportunity operations of mission packages and off-board vehicles.

[P40A / LM012 - TRAINING EQUIPMENT]: Procurement of LCS Mission Module training systems to train LCS crews in the safe and effective use of assigned equipment at LCS Training Facilities (LTF) located in San Diego and Mayport. 

LTF includes tactical watch team training using Common Mission Package Trainer (CMPT) integrated with seaframe Combat Management System (CMS) trainers, a replication of LCS mission bays where LCS MM training systems are moved in and out of the Launch and Recovery (L&R) footprint to train all crews in the safe movement of systems, and revalidate key maintenance skills in the confined mission bay environment. 

Integrated Team Training (ITT) uses the CMPT trainer, with two CMPTs delivered to LCS-1 ITT trainer and LCS-2 ITT trainer in San Diego. CMPT#3 for LCS-1 ITT trainer in Mayport will install in FY2018 and commence operations in FY2018. CMPT#4 procurement required to support second San Diego LCS-2 trainer with installation in FY2018. MCM and SUW integrated team training commenced at San Diego in FY12 and will commence for SUW only in Mayport in FY2018. MCM ITT capability planned in Mayport by FY2019.  CMPTs qualify individuals in a team environment (Train to Qualify) and are also used to certify watch teams (Train to Certify) during off hull periods at LTF.

Each mission area will be delivering training systems as follows: 

MCM: All unmanned vehicles, sensors, and systems in support containers to demonstrate L&R and maintenance tasks. An Integrated virtual shipboard environment (IVSE) (virtual reality) allow sailors to learn and demonstrate crane operator and system remote operations L&R team coordination.  Procurements are for incremental system delivery and support formal training that has commenced in San Diego and will commence in Mayport in FY2019.

SUW: A Mk-46 gun in barbette on a multi-function adapter demonstrates GMM critical maintenance and ammunition loading tasks. MSM AEL equipment is used to support VBSS certification and exercise related shipboard evolutions such as "detainee handling." SSMM module components are used to demonstrate onload tasks. Mission Package Training System (MPTS) is a NAWC TSD PORTS Architecture based training system used in training SUW operators and maintaining gun and missile operator proficiency. Procurements are for incremental system delivery and support formal training that will commence in San Diego and Mayport in FY2020.

ASW: Integrated Virtual Reality Environment (IVSE) demonstrates ASW system L&R tasks. Procurements are for incremental system delivery and support formal training that will commence in San Diego and Mayport in FY2020.

The LCS MM program is also procuring training systems for installation at other shore locations as follows:
Mine Warfare Training Center (MWTC) PT Loma, CA: Training for senior ship and MCM watch standers at Pt Loma, CA. Individuals are trained in MCM mission planning, execution, post mission analysis and re-planning (computer classroom) at MWTC. This course has commenced formal training at Mine Warfare training Center in San Diego (single sited).

Center for Surface Combat Systems Detachment Dam Neck, VA: Fire Controlman (FC) and Gunners Mate (GM) training at Dam Neck VA. MK-50 Modular Gun Weapons System (MGWS) Operations and Maintenance difference 
trainer co-located with the MK-46 Operations and Maintenance trainer. SSMM Operations and Maintenance trainer for technician training at CSCS detachment Dam Neck VA.  Course will teach SSMM Console Operator (SCO) actions, and SSMM Weapons Zone maintenance and loading/unloading tasks.  MK-50 course formal training commenced in FY2015, and SSMM is expected to commence in FY2019.

Fleet ASW Training Center San Diego, CA: Sonar Technician (STG) pipeline training at Pt Loma, CA. Operator training system for AN/SQS-62 operator training using CMPT- like environment.  Course will include an AN/SQWS-62 maintenance trainer for maintenance and deploy/retrieve tasks.   The AN/SLQ-61 LWT Operations and Maintenance course will deliver a trainer for deploy/retrieve tasks.  Procurements support formal training that will commence in FY2020.

[P40A / COMMON MISSION PACKAGE TRAINER (CMPT)]: FY19 procurement is for the fifth CMPT.  CMPT is procured from AAC under SBIR Phase III contract, and when delivered is integrated with ship combat management system (CMS) trainers capable of being connected to the Navy Cooperative Training Environment (NCTE) for participation in Navy and Joint synthetic training events at the LCS Training Facilities in each home port. A total of 6 are  required, with 3 in San Diego and 3 in Mayport. The first CMPT was procured using RDT&EN.  A CMPT consists of a production Mission Package Computing Environment (MPCE) using one of three mission area Mission Package Application Software (MPAS) and integrated with visualization software (common with ship CMS trainer), models and simulations to stimulate tactical MPAS, scenario generator, and instructor control software. Mission area additions (SUW: GUID, and ASW: EMM processing), and IP communications capability for watchstanders are included.

[P40A / CMPT MPTS Tech Refresh/Modernization]: FY19 procurement is for ASW related Technical Insertion (TI) hardware associated with Advanced Capability Baseline (ACB) Escort Mission Module (EMM) software.  FY18 began integration of ASW capability into CMPT.  Hardware procurement is required to support FY20 Ready For Training (RFT) at LTF.

[P40A / MISSION BAY TRAINING DEVICES - MCM]: FY19 procurement is for UISS Technical Training Equipment (TTE).

[P40A / LM015 - CONTAINERS (SHIPPING & SUPPORT)]: Each MP variant uses a base Support Container (SC) which is an ISO compliant shipping container, and comes in two variants: Type I and Type II. The Type I container is a 20-foot ISO container with nominal dimensions of 20' x 8' x 8'. The Type II container is a 10-foot ISO container with nominal dimensions of 10' x 8' x 8'. In both cases the base SC is constructed of high strength steel or aluminum to reduce the overall weight and features a number of standard configuration items.  Mission systems fit inside standard ten- or twenty-foot ISO SCs, or on ISO compliant flat racks and vehicle cradles. The LCS MP zones inside each seaframe mission bay are configured to accommodate the SCs.

[P40A / MCM SUPPORT CONTAINER]: Unit price for the MCM Containers is an average cost that does not reflect the actual cost of each container.  Individual containers for each of the different MCM mission systems have unique requirements and vary in cost.

[P40A / LM016 - MVCS]: The Multiple Vehicle Communications System (MVCS) provides the Littoral Combat Ship (LCS) Mission Modules with the capability to simultaneously communicate with multiple Unmanned Surface Vehicles (USVs) and surfaced Unmanned Underwater Vehicles (UUVs) by providing a common data link and network communication services.  These services include link establishment, link management, communications fail-safes, Emissions Control (EMCON) handling, data routing and protection, packet shaping, Priority of Service (PoS), and automated communications system configuration.  MVCS establishes a common interface for these services in the form of hardware and message definitions to maximize the usefulness of limited radio equipment onboard the LCS seaframe.

[P40A / Shipboard OTH Communications]: The Multi-Vehicle Communications System (MVCS) is a communications management system that provides common line of sight (LOS), over the horizon (OTH), and satellite communications capabilities for simultaneous sensor data transfer and vehicle control of multiple Littoral Combat Ships (LCS) Mission Module unmanned surface vehicles (USV) and unmanned underwater vehicles (UUVs).  MVCS is an open architected communications system that can be adapted to support any radio system.  This funds procurement and delivery of shipboard and small craft radios and to provide OTH capabilities needed by the Mine Countermeasures (MCM) Mission Package.  The Unmanned Aerial Relay (UMAR) extends the existing LOS high bandwidth capability  (12 Mbps) range out to 30 NM through use of a tethered quad-copter air relay.  The second solution is the High Frequency Ground Wave (HFGW) radio which provides a direct high bandwidth comms link (452 kbps to 2 vehicles) operating out to 30 NM, without relying on a relay platform.

[P40A / LM900 - CONSULTING SERVICES]: Provides program management support, engineering and technical support, studies, analysis and evaluation on mission package systems.

Justification.val:
FY 2019 funding is an increase from FY 2018 due to the procurement of six (6) shipboard MPCE systems including technology refresh to meet LCS ship delivery schedules. FY2019 also funds the procurement of the first four (4) MPCE Sonar Signal Processing racks to support the ASW Escort Mission Module (EMM) processing requirements on LCS 22 through LCS 25.    

FY 2019 also support the procurement of training equipment to support the outfit of the LCS Training Facility (LTF) in Mayport, FL to support training of Freedom Variant crews. Current San Diego, CA training facilities do not meet the throughput requirements to provide trained sailors to meet Fleet operational needs on both coasts. These funds are required to stand up the (LTF) in Mayport, FL. which will focus on training for the Freedom Variant crews.  Training equipment will include one Common Mission Package Trainer (CMPT), ASW Mission Package training equipment and MCM Mission Package Training equipment.   

Also in FY 2019 Cyber Security and Anti-Jam toolkits, required for each Multiple Vehicle Communications System (MVCS)installation will be procured.  The MVCS provides the Littoral Combat Ship (LCS) Mission Modules with the capability to simultaneously communicate with multiple Unmanned Surface Vehicles (USVs) and surfaced Unmanned Underwater Vehicles (UUVs) by providing a common data link and network communication services.

Name.@footnote: AN/AQS-20A prior configuration AQS-20 sonars and are non-deployable assets.  AQS-20C are the production representative, deployable configuration and are procured in BLI 1601
AN/AQS-20A prior configuration AQS-20 sonars and are non-deployable assets.  AQS-20C are the production representative, deployable configuration and are procured in BLI 1601

The Open System Architecture (OSA) and high performance COTS MPCE Sonar Signal Processing hardware, is provided as an adjunct to the Mission Package Computing Environment (MPCE) will be fielded to meet in yard need dates for LCS 22 - LCS 28.    The MPCE Sonar Signal Processing will provide an opportunity to integrate emergent, transformational ASW technological improvements that were previously unachievable. The sonar signal processing will require periodic upgrades to remain effective well into the 21st century and to pace the threat. Software upgrades target capability increases in high interest areas as prescribed by the Fleet and captured in campaign analysis. To achieve this, this project will package and deliver incremental upgrades every four years to the production program via an ACB development process by inserting maturing ASW technologies and addressing hardware technology obsolescence.
Technical Training Equipment that is integrated with Ship Combat Management System to conduct stand-alone MP team training and integrated LCS Team training.
Procurement of ECP's, Tech Refresh, and Modernization to keep CMPT and MPTS current with delivered baseline.

Procurement of MCM components located in an LCS mission bay to replicate the afloat environment as required to support individual qualification and team certification associated with routine and corrective system maintenance in a constrained environment, transportation in the mission bay, pre- / post- operation system maintenance; system launch and recovery.

FiscalYear.@footnote: Unit price for the MCM Containers is an average cost that does not reflect the cost of each container.  Individual containers for each of the different MCM mission systems have unique requirements and vary in cost.

Name.@footnote: Quantity reflects total amount of Unmanned Aerial Relay (UMAR) ship-sets, High Frequency Ground Wave (HFGW) ship-sets and HFGW vehicle sets.  Unit price is average of all components.
